sections.heading: MINIREVIEW
sections.text: Abstract: Light is a nearly ideal stimulus for molecular systems. It delivers information encoded in form of wavelengths and their intensities with high precision in space and time. Light is a mild trigger that does not permanently contaminate targeted samples. Its energy can be reversibly transformed into molecular motion, polarity or flexibility changes. This leads to sophisticated functions at the supramolecular and macroscopic level - from light-triggered nanomaterials to photocontrol over biological systems. New methods and molecular adapters of light are reported almost daily. Recently reported applications of photoresponsive systems, particularly azobenzenes, spiropyrans, diarylethenes and indigoids, for smart materials and photocontrol of biological setups are described here with the aim to demonstrate that the 21st century became the Age of Enlightenment – “Le siècle des Lumières”- in molecular sciences.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text: Light is electromagnetic radiation, which visible spectrum spans from 400 nm to 700 nm.[1] The primary properties of light are: its intensity, propagation direction, wavelength spectrum, and polarization, while its speed in vacuum, almost 300.000 km/s, is one of the fundamental constants of Nature. Light interacts with matter. It can cause formation or dissociation of covalent bonds, as well as reversible changes in geometry, polarity or rigidity of particular molecular systems. This review is focused on reversible changes induced with light at the molecular level, which result in interesting macroscopic effects. In the first part, important classes of reversible molecular photoswitches are briefly presented. Well-established classes: of azobenzenes, spiropyrans, stilbenes and diarylethenes, as well as indigoids as an example of emerging switches, have been selected for further detailed description, with bias on visible and NIR light addressability, where applicable. The diversity of their applications in light-triggered materials and machines, and ultimately in photochromic systems applicable in the biological context, has been demonstrated in the following two parts. The discussed materials provide representative examples of switchable nanoparticles, elastomers and liquid crystals, MOF systems, light-triggered sol-gel systems, photoswitchable catalysts and molecular motors, as well as examples of solar energy storage and molecular logic. Biological applications have been divided by classes of photomodulated biopolymers and concluded with bioactive photochromic small molecules.

sections.heading: 1. Molecular photoswitches
sections.text: Photochromism is a reversible phototransformation of chemical species between two forms having different absorption spectra. This transformation – photoisomerization – affects various molecular properties, such as geometry, rigidity, dielectric constant, or refractive index.[2] Molecules that reversibly transform the energy of light this way are called “molecular photoswitches”. They can be components of pigments for the rewritable compact discs and DVDs, 3D data storage systems,[3] systems of vision in the human eye,[4] or light-driven molecular motors.[5] The majority of described molecular photoswitches are based on the structure of azobenzene, diarylethene, or spiropyran. However, novel interesting scaffolds are continuously reported.[6]

sections.heading: 1.1. Azobenzenes (AB)
sections.text: In non-substituted azobenzene (AB), the –N=N- bond between aromatic residues undergoes photoisomerization under UV light irradiation from the stable E-isomer (trans-AB) to the thermodynamically unstable Z-form (cis-AB). The latter returns to the E-configuration upon irradiation with blue light or by thermal equilibration (Figure 1a).[7] In the last decade, several modifications of the azobenzene structure switchable entirely with visible light were demonstrated. Notably, numerous azobenzenes with red-shifted absorption maxima[8] can be obtained by multiple substitutions at the positions ortho to the azo bond, particularly with methoxy groups,[9] chlorine,[10] or fluorine atoms (Figure 1b).[11] Traditionally, azobenzene derivatives have been prepared by azo coupling or Mills reaction. However, these processes may become inefficient due to steric hindrance or in electron-poor aromatic systems. This prompted application of non-standard reaction conditions[12] or synthetic methods, including late-stage chlorination,[13] or coupling of organolithium compounds to diazonium salts (Figure 1c).[14] Arylazopyrazoles, -pyrroles and - imidazoles with excellent bistability parameters addressable with UV or visible light were also reported.[15] Modifications with fused dioxane rings[16] or hydrazone motif[17] resulted in molecules switchable at the near-infrared (NIR) light range. Cyclic azobenzenes (diazocines)[18] can be also isomerized with visible light.[19] However, in contrary to the previous examples, here the Z-isomer is the thermodynamically stable form (Figure 1d).

sections.heading: 1.3. Stilbenes and diarylethenes
sections.text:
Photochemistry of stilbenes is related to that of azobenzenes. Its molecular geometry change caused by photoisomerization is similar to the analogous azobenzenes, but the difference in dipole moments between the photoisomers is much smaller. Thermal stability of the cis (Z) –C=C- bond is, however, higher than its dinitrogen analogue. Therefore its thermal equilibration to the stable E isomer at ambient temperature is insignificant (Figure 3a, R = H). Instead, irreversible 6π electrocyclization of
the Z-stilbene followed by oxidation (dehydrogenation) leading to aromatic phenantrene analogues takes place. It is the main hurdle in applications based on reversible photoswitching.[24]

Substitution of the aryl rings in the positions 2- and 6- of stilbenes (ortho-positions) suppresses the irreversible oxidative aromatization and thus enables reversible photoisomerization, even in the presence of oxygen (Figure 3a, R ≠ H).[25] However, thermal lifetime of such carbocyclic disubstituted dihydrophenantrenes is in the range of minutes at ambient temperature. It can be significantly elongated by replacing phenyl rings with heteroaromatic systems, such as thiophene rings. Further stabilization of the system (by suppression of the Z-E isomerization step in the open form) can be achieved by incorporation of the double bond into a small ring system (e.g. a cyclopentene) (Figure 3b). Overall, these modifications of the stilbene scaffold led to construction of thermally irreversible photochromic systems resistant to photodegradation.[26] Upon light-induced cyclization, the colorless open form switches to the colorful closed form that differs not only in absorption spectrum, but also in refractive index, dielectric constant, and redox potential. However, changes in molecular geometry of the isomers are minor, and thus the isomerization can occur quickly also in a solid matrix, in contrary to most other photochromic molecules. Therefore these switches are applicable in optical data storage devices based on reversible disruption of the πelectron conjugation between the opposite ends of the diarylethene molecules with light. DAEs with extended conjugated substituents can become bidirectionally switchable with visible light.[27] Other strategy, based on triplet-sensitization, exploits e.g. metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) by connecting the switch with metalligand complexes (Figure 3c).[28]

sections.heading: 1.4 Indigoids
sections.text:
Indigo is a common blue dye with extraordinarily high resistance on photobleaching. Its structure was first reported by Adolf von Baeyer in 1883.[29] Its enormous photostability due to efficient excited state proton transfer (ESPT) prevents the photoisomerization.[30] However, the trans-cis photoisomerization becomes possible after N-alkyl or N-acyl substitution of the indigo system (Figure 4a). There, the Z-isomers often show relatively short lifetimes, although e.g. recently reported bis-N-arylsubstituted indigos exhibit red-light switching (660 nm) to >80% Z-isomer with the half-life of up to 7 h.[31] The corresponding mono-Narylsubstituted derivatives show lower Z-isomer ratio (c.a. 40 %) at the photostationary state (PSS), and their lifetime is strongly dependent (from seconds to minutes) from water content in the solvent (consistent with the ESPT mechanism).[32] Hemiindigo (HI) was reported along with indigo in 1883.[29] However, its photochromism was also demonstrated more than a century later (Figure 4b).[33] This system is obtained by condensation of indoxyl acetate with respective aldehydes. Hemiindigo derivatives with electron-rich aromatic substituens demonstrated mutual photoswitching with red and green light with PSS > 90 % for both isomers and thermal half-lifes up to 83 years at 25 0C. Due to similar energies of both isomers E and Z, thermal equilibration does not pronouncedly favor any of them.[34]

sections.heading: 1.5 Other photochromic scaffolds
sections.text:
Brief description of photoisomerization mechanisms and significant recent applications for other important classes of molecular photoswitches, not discussed in details in following sections of this review, is provided below.[6] Overcrowded alkenes belong to the category of chirooptical molecular switches. In enantiomeric photobistable molecules (chirochromism), interconversion of two enantiomers occurs at single wavelength by changing handedness of circularly polarized light (CPL). In diastereomeric photobistable molecules (diastereo-photochromism), interconversion between two diastereomers occurs by irradiation at different wavelengths.[39] In overcrowded alkenes, cis-trans photoisomerization is accompanied by simultaneous reversal of helicity (Figure 5a).[40] Chiroptical molecular switches that show directional motion are prototypical synthetic molecular motors.[41] They have been incorporated into a nano-car model,[42] immobilized on solid surfaces,[43] or applied as asymmetric catalysts.[44] Imines, similar to alkenes, may undergo both thermal and photochemical isomerization. They can constitute rotary molecular motors based on imine syn–anti isomerization.[45] Directionality can be forced on these processes by introducing a stereogenic center close to the C=N bond, resulting in iminebased unidirectional molecular motors (Figure 5b).[46] A structurally simplified system, based on camphorquinonederived imines, demonstrated that in principle every chiral imine could be a molecular motor in response to light and heat.[47] Donor-acceptor Stenhouse adducts (DASA) are visible and NIR light-responsive negative photochromic molecules. The
ground state is a colorful push-pull system, constituted by electron donor and acceptor connected with a conjugated triene. It photobleaches to colorless cyclopentenone, which then thermally returns to the triene (Figure 5c). Switching parameters of the first DASA generation (donor: secondary alkyl amine, acceptor: Meldrum’s or barbituric acid)[48] have been upgraded by introducing aniline derivatives as donors (2nd generation)[49] and tailoring the carbon acid acceptor group,[50] to ultimatelly enable far-red switching with high thermodynamic stability of the triene. DASA are synthesized in a modular way from furfural, and have been applied for model drug delivery systems, as well as for the design of photoresponsive nanoparticles, surfaces, and liquid crystals.[51] Acylhydrazones are highly fatigue-resistant compounds, easily prepared on large scales within hours, yet covering a wide range of thermal half-lives of their (Z)-isomers, from short-lived to thermally stable. They exhibit good quantum yields and excellent band separation between the absorbance maxima of (E)- and (Z)-isomers (Figure 5d) in the UV or visible region. Among them, rare negative photochromic systems have been also demonstrated.[52] The (Z)-isomer of acylhydrazones, usually disfavored, can be stabilized with properly introduced hydrogen bondings.[53] This effect was used for pyridyl-acylhydrazones, in switchable cinchona-derived enantioselective organocatalysts,[54] as well as in the first photoswitchable heteroditopic ion-pair receptor in which both cation and anion binding sites are simultaneously and reversibly switched.[55] Fulgides are potential candidates for erasable and rewritable organic optical memory systems because of good spectral separation of photoisomers, stability, and efficient switching. Their photochromism is based on the reversible photochemical conrotatory electrocyclization of the 1,3,5-hexatriene moiety. (Figure 5e) The cyclizations of heterocyclic derivatives such as furoyl- and indolylfulg(im)ides are thermally irreversible.[56] The photochromic reaction involves the open E-form - colorless and conformationally mobile (which often remains in equilibrium with another open Z-form) and the closed C-form - colored and rigid. Suppressing the cyclization path by chemical design resulted in a fulgide-based unidirectional rotary molecular motor.[57] Conjugation of the fulgide fragment with spirooxazine yielded biphotochromic switches with significantly enhanced static second-order nonlinear optical (NLO) response.[58] whereas conjugation of fulgides with diarylethenes resulted in molecular keypad locks[59] and molecular XOR logic gates[60] Norbornadiene/quadricyclane (NBD/QC). The conversion of solar energy is currently achieved either via a photovoltaic or a photo(electro)chemical route, yielding electrical energy or storable fuels, respectively. An alternative for energy storage is the use of intramolecular processes (e.g. reversible switching). For this purpose, norbornadiene (NBD) is one of the most promising molecular scaffolds. NBD can be photoconverted to its metastable, strained, and energy-rich isomer quadricyclane (QC) (Figure 5f) via a triplet-state mechanism, usually with photosensitizers (acetophenone, Michler’s ketone), with UV or visible light (up to 700 nm) – depending on the substitution pattern.[61] Upon cycloreversion of QC back to NBD, the system can release up to 100 kJ/mol of thermal energy, which defines it as a solar fuel. sections.heading: 2. Photoresponsive materials and nanostructures
sections.text: Photoswitches can be integrated with various molecular and supramolecular scaffolds in order to reversibly modulate their micro- and macroscopic properties. Below we describe a few representative examples out of numerous fascinating lighttriggered materials, mainly nanoparticles, porous frameworks, and soft materials, recently reported in literature

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials and nanostructures based on azobenzenes
sections.text:
Upon photoisomerization, azobenzenes (AB) change their polarity (trans-AB: µ = 0 D, cis-AB: µ =3 D) and their molecular geometry (the “end-to-end” distance changes by c.a. 3.5 Å). The E-isomer of AB (trans-AB) is 10-12 kcal/mol more stable than the Z-AB molecule (cis-AB).[7] These changes in physical properties have been exploited to control behavior of polymers, nanoparticles and supramolecular materials decorated with AB molecules. Superparamagnetic Fe3O4 nanoparticles decorated with AB provided dual-controlled material, which self-assembly state was controlled with light and magnetic force.[69] Two differently substituted AB derivatives provided orthogonal light-driven self-assembly of respectively functionalized nanoparticles (Figure 6).[70]

polar molecular guests, as well as to enhance rates of chemical reactions (hydrolysis, Diels-Alder cycloaddition) in the lightdependent manner.[72] Further demonstrations include a light-driven “caterpillar” fabricated from a monolytic photochromic liquid crystal elastomer film (Figure 7a).[73] Another liquid crystalline polymer film doped with visible-light-responsive fluorinated azobenzenes is capable of continuous chaotic oscillatory motion upon exposure to ambient sunlight.[74] Potential applications of such nanodevices powered by sunlight may range from autonomous self-propelling machines to self-cleaning surfaces. Photomodulation of 2D-polymers has been demonstrated with UV-light-responsive AB grafted to carbon nanotubes[76] or graphene[77] to construct solar thermal cells. Low-MW azobenzene was also developed as liquid solar thermal fuel, although limited exothermicity of this material still needs optimization.[78] Another AB derivative constitutes a molecular spin switch, bistable at room temperature.[79] Irradiation (500 nm) of the trans-configured nickel complex induces coordination of the tethered pyridine ligand and concomitant electronic rearrangement from a diamagnetic to a paramagnetic state. The process is fully reversible with 435 nm light without fatigue or degradation (Figure 8). The molecular spin switch has been applied for photoswitching of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) contrast by a factor of 6.7 – the change clearly visible with a clinical MRI scanner.[80] According to the same principle, an iron(III)-porphyrin complex with a photochromic axial ligand upon irradiation with two different wavelengths showed reversible switching between the low-spin (S = 1/2) and high-spin (S = 5/2) state in solution, constituting a simple model for the first step of the cytochrome P450 catalytic cycle.[81]

Another group of photoresponsive materials decorated with photochromic residues are metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) – nanoporous crystalline solids composed of metal nodes and
organic linker molecules.[83] Photoswitching of such MOF powders and thin layers (Figure 9) leads to remote-controlled release of guest molecules,[84] switching the adsorption capacity of various gases,[85] or to continuously tunable membrane separation of molecular mixtures.[82] Some of such MOFs are switchable entirely with visible light.[86] Light-triggered responsive hydrogels have been finding promising applications in materials science and biomedical research. Irradiation of either physically (non-covalently) or chemically (covalently) cross-linked photochromic hydrogels can cause abrupt changes in physical properties such as pore size, elasticity, viscosity, water-swelling ratio, and affinity for specific chemicals.[87] By exploring the light-dependent affinity change of azobenzenes to β-cyclodextrins, photochromic hydrogels can be reversibly dissipated with UV[88] or visible light,[89] due to reversible cross-linking of polymeric chains. During dissipation, they can release encapsulated cargo molecules (e.g. proteins).[89] Other type of photochromic supramolecular assembly, based on low-MW cyclic dipeptides (2,5- diketopiperazines) bearing azobenzene-substituted (S)-alanine residues, results in hydrogel formation under physiological conditions. The gels can encapsulate several common classes of unmodified drugs or biopolymers and reversibly dissipate to fluids upon irradiation with UV,[90] or visible light (Figure 10),[91] concomitantly releasing the cargo in its active form. Photocontrol with green light over a simple biological system – growth of bacterial cultures - was achieved using the hydrogels filled with an antibiotic ciprofloxacin.[91]

Molecular motors (myosin, actin, proton pumps) are biological machines essential for creating movements in living organisms. Their mode of action – directional transport along molecular track – can be mimicked with synthetic systems, called molecular walkers. In one of such systems, the E Z photoisomerization of a stilbene provides a driving force for the walker to “step” onto the central stilbene unit, while subsequent Z E isomerization results in a majority of the walkers being transported away from the stilbene group in a direction determined by which foot–track interaction is labilized next (disulfide bonds become labile with bases, hydrazone bonds – with acids), simulating the Brownian ratchet mechanism (Figure 12).[98]

sections.heading: 3. Photoswitches at the interface of biology
sections.text:
Light may be considered a very clean, non-contaminating “reagent” that can be delivered with high spatiotemporal precision. Therefore molecular photoswitches recently became important tools for “clean”, selective control over unitary processes in complex biological systems. Several recent examples of biopolymers (peptides, oligonucleotides, oligosaccharides) decorated with photoswitches, as well as photochromic small molecules possessing biological or pharmaceutical activity have been discussed in the following section. As the light penetration depth inside complex organisms (e.g. human tissues) generally increases with its wavelength, photoswitches operational under visible light irradiation (preferably red) or in the near-IR (NIR) range are particularly valuable for in vivo applications. UV-light-driven isomerization (typical for the most common photochromic molecules) is usually more suitable for in vitro experiments. But if the experimental system is properly designed, valuable results can be also obtained in cellular models, or even with living organisms.

sections.heading: 3.1. Photochromic oligonucleotides
sections.text:
Combinations of oligonucleotides (ON) with molecular photoswitches are intensively explored in order to photomodulate the ON structure (e.g. light-induced formation of DNA G-quadruplexes[111]) and functions - ranging from in vitro photomodulation of DNA duplex stability, over systems useful for material sciences and nanotechnology, to complex applications in chemical biology. A prominent long-term goal here is the ability to manipulate and to study biological processes in vivo. A photoswitch can be covalently inserted into the ON backbone, it can replace a whole nucleoside or a part of it, or interact with the ON chain non-covalently (usually with cationic residues binding to phosphates of the ON backbone).[112] Replacement of one nucleotide or deoxyribonucleotide unit with a diol covalently coupled to a photoswitch (usually D-threoninol bearing an azobenzene (tAzo)[113]), or with an azobenzene Cnucleoside (pAzo, mAzo),[114] results in the stabilization of a complementary duplex by one of the photoisomers – here by π−π stacking of trans-azobenzene with neighboring nucleobases. The other photoisomer destabilizes the duplex – either by the increased steric hindrance or removal of the stabilizing π−π stacking interaction component (Figure 15).

This effect has been used i.a. to photomodulate expression of green fluorescent protein (GFP) in a cell-free translation system, by incorporation of two photochromic units (here, the Dthreoninol-derived (S-DM)-tAzo) into the T7 promoter region of the GFP gene. Here, stronger intercalation of the transphotoisomer inhibited binding of the T7 RNA polymerase.[115] In principle, the non-natural photochromic modules of this architecture can be synthetically incorporated into one of two DNA primers and PCR-amplified, resulting in dsDNA strands with the photochromic “overhang”. DNA ligation with T4 DNA

This method was demonstrated on a 42- meric dsDNA, but can potentially deliver full azobenzenemodified genes.[116] Using light-driven affinity changes of azobenzene-decorated (tAzo) DNA strands to a partially complementary “DNA walker”, it was possible to realize its reversible and autonomous movement along a track of three anchorage sites, which was controlled by UV (370 nm) or visible (>465 nm) light irradiation.[117] Peptidonucleic acids (PNA) are synthetic nucleic acid analogs, in which canonical nucleobases are attached onto a peptoid backbone.[118] They are chemically robust and physiologically stable. PNA oligomers efficiently hybridize to DNA and RNA through standard Watson–Crick and Hoogsteen base pairing, with high affinity and sequence specificity. Therefore PNA oligomers found applications for in vivo nucleotide sensing,[119] or as promising antisense agents.[120] Short triplex-forming PNA oligomers terminated with azobenzene-containing monomeric units have been used to photomodulate the transcription process of egfp gene with T7 RNA polymerase.[121]

Upon photoisomerization, the DNA binding affinity decreases 18-fold.[122] Another transcription factor – MyoD – has been cross-linked (Figure 16) to accommodate the cis-azobenzene in the helical conformation (i,i+7 Cys).[123] The cross-linked peptide (cis-PhotoMyoD) binds DNA three orders of magnitude more tightly, than MyoD, and with significantly increased specificity. The β-turn is another structural motif that can be photomodulated by covalent incorporation of azobenzenes into peptides. Reversible light-induced switching between aggregates,[127] or unstructured peptide[128] and a well-defined βhairpin structure have been demonstrated as models for the folding and stability of protein β-sheets. An AB-containing cell-permeable photoswitchable peptide probe was capable of modulating epigenetic cellular states by disruption of an essential protein–protein interaction within the histone methyltransferase MLL1 core complex, and thus influencing growth of leukemia cells.[129] A fluorinated AB has been just recently applied to prepare probes which display modulated nucleosome-binding capacity upon visible-light irradiation. This technique may give rise to new optoepigenetic tools for conditional modulation of nucleosomal DNA accessibility.[130] Photomodulation of peptide bioactivity was also demonstrated with diarylethenes (DAE). Although DAE photoisomerisation does not induce large geometry changes, significant difference in cytotoxicity has been observed upon photoisomerization of DAE-containing analogue of a cyclic peptide gramicidin S, presumably due to meaningful changes in backbone flexibility.[131] This compound has been successfully applied on a tumor animal model as an alternative to oxygen-dependent photodynamic anticancer therapy.[132] A hemithioindigo (HTI)-based amino acid was incorporated into gramicidin ion channels and could be used to modulate the ion current with light.[133] A HTI unit appended in the backbone was also used to follow dynamics of linear and cyclic beta-hairpin model peptides.[134] Chemical incorporation of molecular photoswitches into protein scaffold can be also efficiently supported with computational design, which became a powerful tool in protein engineering.[135] The photoresponsive yeast cytosine deaminase with 3-fold activity photomodulation was recently designed using algorithms from Rosetta family (Figure 17).[136] This methodology will likely be extended over a variety of other enzymes.

sections.heading: 3.5. Photochromic bioactive small molecules
sections.text:
An approach complementary to covalently decorating biopolymers with photoswitches is synthesis of photochromic bioactive molecules that reversibly change their activity upon irradiation. This approach, called photopharmacology,[145] has been demonstrated particularly in the area of ion channel inhibitors, antibacterial and antiproliferative agents. Activities of common antibiotics, i.a. quinolones, were modulated with UV[146] or visible light (trimethoprim,[147] gramicidin[131]). Implementation of the azobenzene scaffold into a microtubule dynamics modulator combretastatin resulted in photostatins - with over 250-fold change of the cytotoxic activity upon light-driven isomerization.[148] A simple anesthetic propofol bound to an azobenzene exhibited photomodulation of GABAA receptors.[149] Azobenzene-bearing photoswitchable ceramides enable reversible switching of lipid domains in raft-mimicking supported lipid bilayers,[150] whereas photoswitchable diacylglycerol (DAG) analogues enabled optical control of protein kinase C to study DAG signaling.[151] Optical control of the cannabinoid receptor signaling was achieved by switching of an azobenzenefunctionalized Δ9‑Tetrahydrocannabinol (Figure 18).[152]

Lipoxygenases (LOX) are lipid-peroxidizing enzymes involved in development of numerous inflammatory diseases, asthma or osteoporosis. A photoswitchable hemithioindigo-based LOX inhibitor (ebselen analogue) exhibited up to 33-fold increase in the inhibition efficiency upon photoisomerization.[153]

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
The aim of this minireview was to provide the reader with a digest of the diverse recent applications of molecular photoswitches for controlling materials and biological systems. Representative examples of implementation of azobenzenes, spiropyrans, stilbenes, diarylethenes, and indigoids into nanoparticles, MOFs, soft materials, molecular motors and photoswitchable catalysis, as well as into biopolymers and photopharmacology agents have been discussed. Selected applications for other important classes of photoswitches have been also mentioned. Based on these examples, we conclude that photochromic molecules constitute a versatile class of molecules, which due to their unique properties enabled
enormous diversity of tasks at the nano- and macroscopic level to be achieved up to date. Yet still, photoswitches are far from being universal. Each class of compounds possesses serious limitations (e.g. azobenzenes are often thermally unstable, and diarylethenes exhibit very little geometry photomodulation) that limit their applicability. Thus, the basic scaffolds are iteratively optimized to expand the application scope. Switching soft materials requires sufficient time for equilibration of the system, in order to observe the desired macroscopic effects - thus adequate lifetime of the unstable photoisomer is needed. Practical systems for solar energy conversion need to exhibit sufficient molar capacity of energy storage, but they also need to be appropriately stable and safe for handling (highly flammable or explosive compounds are definitely undesired). Photochromic biopolymers and photopharmacophores are intended for in vivo use - photoswitches addressable with visible light (preferably in the “therapeutic window”, >600 nm) and functional under physiological conditions are highly demanded here. Finally, molecular motors need to maximize the conversion of light energy into directional movement, in order to reduce its thermal dissipation. Addressing all these challenges by intense investigation of the existing and novel photochromic structures is crucial for further expansion of photocontrollable systems. The author envisions that advance in understanding and control of photophysical properties in molecular switches will increasingly stimulate development of novel materials with precise spatiotemporal control of their properties, as well as advanced tools for accurate modulation of biological systems.

metadata.abstractText: Light is a nearly ideal stimulus for molecular systems. It delivers information encoded in form of wavelengths and their intensities with high precision in space and time. Light is a mild trigger that does not permanently contaminate targeted samples. Its energy can be reversibly transformed into molecular motion, polarity or flexibility changes. This leads to sophisticated functions at the supramolecular and macroscopic level from light-triggered nanomaterials to photocontrol over biological systems. New methods and molecular adapters of light are reported almost daily. Recently reported applications of photoresponsive systems, particularly azobenzenes, spiropyrans, diarylethenes and indigoids, for smart materials and photocontrol of biological setups are described here with the aim to demonstrate that the 21st century became the Age of Enlightenment – “Le siècle des Lumières”in molecular sciences.
